awd_titl_txt: Biotechnology of thiocyanate degradation: an exploration using meta-omics tools to understand the microbial communities responsible for remediation of mining wastewater
awd_abstract_narration:
Biotechnology of thiocyanate degradation: an exploration using meta-omics tools to understand the microbial communities responsible for remediation of mining wastewater
 
Wastewater from gold mining, coal and steel processing, and other industrial operations often contains the chemical thiocyanate, which can be harmful to human health and the environment.  In last two decades, engineering research has yielded progress toward the complete breakdown of thiocyanate by microorganisms. This work primarily focused on the chemical and physical parameters of the process and largely ignored the biology of the microorganisms involved. As a result, current efforts to harness the potential of microorganisms in the form of on-site industrial biotechnology yield inefficient and incomplete remediation. Thiocyanate is degraded by microorganisms that function within the context of complex microbial communities. Metagenomics, metatranscriptomics, and metaproteomics methods allow researchers to study the metabolic capacities and activities of all organisms in such communities. 

Using these approaches to interrogate samples from a bioreactor treating thiocyanate in the laboratory, investigators will learn which organisms are responsible for breakdown of thiocyanate and which have the potential to degrade byproducts as well. Specifically, thiocyanate byproducts are nitrogen compounds such as ammonium and nitrate; these need to be removed prior to release or re-use of treated water.  The nitrogen cycle is a biogeochemical process that also occurs in the environment and is harnessed for domestic wastewater treatment.  Thus, results from this study will have the basic relevance to natural systems and may suggest improvements to wastewater treatment processes as well. Graduate and undergraduate students from the US will travel to South Africa to work in the laboratory of the collaborator, gaining valuable international experience.

por.por_cntn:
Technologies that employ consortia of microorganisms to cost-effectively and safely treat contaminated water hold enormous potential, but they are often limited by lack of understanding of how the systems work and of ways to change operating conditions to improve function.  Thiocyanate is a toxic compound produced from cyanide during industrial activities, especially mining. 

Motivated by the need to bioremediate huge quantities of thiocyanate contaminated water, especially in countries such as South Africa and Australia where fresh water is a limited resource, we conducted extensive research to define the membership, individual microbial capacities and roles of specific members in thiocyanate-degrading consortia. (Figures 1 and 2). We identified previously undescribed bacteria that break down thiocyanate and the pathways by which this occurs, as well as those that metabolize ammonia and sulfur compound breakdown products and explored the range of conditions under which these bacteria proliferate. We discovered that thiocyanate degradation is primarily carried out by autotrophic Thiobacilli (organisms that can fix CO2 and thus do not require organic compounds normally added to the system), especially when thiocyanate concentrations are high. Thus, we conducted a series of long-running laboratory experiments to study how the abundance of these bacteria and other community members change as a function of thiocyanate concentration with and without added organic carbon. We identified a previously unrecognized autotrophic Rhizobiales bacterium that is present at low abundance when thiocyanate concentrations are low and that reproducibly dominate reactors to which organic carbon has not been added when concentrations are high (up to 2000 ppm thiocyanate).

An important finding from the main series of experiments was that we could consistently select for both bacteria and their associated communities by shifting experimental conditions.  Similarly, we found that obligate ultra-small bacterial symbionts and their inferred bacterial host cells can be cultivated at high abundance by selection of the appropriate thiocyanate concentration in reactors to which organic substrate was continuously added.  This opens the way for future studies of these enigmatic microbial associations. We near-comprehensively reconstructed genomes for all members of the thiocyanate-degrading microbial communities, including obligate symbionts, remarkable large phages and a variety of eukaryotes (whose genomes have until recently been impossible to recover from community DNA sequence datasets). We extended the work by applying our genomic approaches to consortia established in Australia and being tested for their utility for onsite remediation of a gold mining tailings pond and achieved similar results. 

Overall, the research provided extensive insight into how thiocyanate can be remediated biologically and demonstrated the value of genomic and proteomic information for redesign of biotechnologies. Beyond the broader impact of the findings for water treatment, the project disseminated state of the art bioinformatics methods into the chemical engineering field where they have been rarely employed and to university settings, student groups and in the case of South Africa, a country where this expertise did not exist.
